column7: Beach is sandy and quite narrow, so some launching experience is needed. It is crowded as well. But the guys from the kiteschool are very friendly and willing to help. It is white sand and about 50m and many kilometers long. Many kiters prefer to set up in the grassy lot (which doubles as a parking lot) next to the windsurfing school.
The beach is sandy, but to get in the water, you have to walk over some stones. Some grassy areas on the beach.
Not so great beach but perfect to launch and ride. Sand with some coral stones. With NE winds launch in water.
Sandy beach. Little rocks to walk over to get into the water.
Sandy beach with lots of pieces of broken coral. Plenty of space to launch however tourist boats do limit space of entering the water.
Entrance to the water with lots of rocks.

Clean, sandy beach with waves depending on swell direction. Lots of space, but be aware of sunbathers and swimmers, specially during weekends. Beginners need to go with assistance, and follow the rules.

Shoreline is flat shelf. Long but narrow sandy beach. Launch from point and stay leeward of exposed reef rock. Land same area or downwind sandy spots. Good to walk the bay to get a feel for rocky/sandy sections of beach.

Soft sand, designated swimming areas with small channels to exit. The only draw back is the hot-launch you have to do. Be sure to keep the kite over the water and body drag out for the first 10 meters or so. Body drag in to beach after session.
Small sandy beach. Long bay, enough space.
No real beach. You need a boat to get to the spots and need to start from the water.
Nice, sandy bay with lots of space. At the west end far away there are some big rocks with shore break
Sandy beach close by the point. Launch from here or from a boat to get to the break. Flat reefs in front of the beach.
Small beach. Some sun bathers around.
The beach has beautiful white fine sand. It has lots of space to safely land and launch your kite.
To launch a kite walk further left, away from the sun umbrellas.

The beach stretches for about 2 km length and it consists of soft and nice sand. On the leeward side of the bay, the peninsula of Moule a' Chique borders the sickle shaped beach preventing the kitesurfers from drifting off. The kitesurfing area is located leeward side of the bay and gives the possibility to land and launch safely the kite.
The beach is a sandy beach. The launching area is good.
Leather back sea turtles are breeding during the summer months - as the site is a nature preserve park it may be not advised to kite during the breeding season May to September.
Very small launch spot but makes up for on the water.
Big beach with sand and grass.
Small sandy beaches can be found on the 4 islands.
Nice white sandy beach. Very narrow on the west facing beach, a bit wider on the east facing beach.
The beach is very narrow and it is hard to launch the kite properly. I always used to start the kite Russian style as this was the only way to avoid starting while swimming.
As the wind is onshore and the palms are very near you will have to launch the kite in the water - however the bay is very shallow and it is no problem to launch wading.
Mayaro Bay has the longest beach in Trinidad. Lots of space. Nice soft sand.
Beautiful paradise white beach. Entrance fee (3 USD).
Sandy beach. Plenty of room at low tide, high tide you may need help launching from car park. Local kiters and windsurfers are very friendly and helpful. Crowded with drunk swimmers at weekends.

Long sandy beach with a few shells, usually wider around the river mouth. Best at low tide but incoming and outgoing tides are ok too. If tide is extremely high kites can be launched/landed on parking lot (watch out for cars, trees and power lines in the back).

The beach is long, wide and sandy, making it ideal for beginners and self launching. It is important that one launches from Kite Beach because further down the beach the break is covered with broken conch shells. The location is very remote, quite possible to be the only one on the beach during a windy day. The beach stretches for miles, yet there are only a few homes located on the beach. Wild dogs roam the beach and the local rancher walks his horses on the beach in the early morning.
Sandy beach with lots of space. Beach can be littered with Conch shells which easily damage your kite. If you are going to ride the waves to the NE be careful of shallow coral reef.
10km long, sandy beach with lots of space. Many resorts along the beach with sunbathers, just move out of their way.
Long sandy beach. Sunbathers in front of the resort.
Great launching area at the south end of the Five Cays beach, next to a cafe.
4km long, sandy beach with lots of space.
No crowds to speak of really as the whole island is quiet. Stunning beach.
Postcard scene. Can be busy with yachts at times and so be careful of other beach users.
Perhaps the finest beach in the world, definitely one of the quietest - it's normal to walk for miles and never see a soul. Sand is like talcum powder.
Limited launching beaches, talk with locals about sites. Best launch is in the middle of the sound from a dingy.
Very fine sandy beach. Lots of space.
Perhaps the finest beach in the world, definitely one of the quietest - it's normal to walk for miles and never see a soul. Sand is like talcum powder.
Perhaps the finest beach in the world, definitely one of the quietest - it's normal to walk for miles and never see a soul. Sand is like talcum powder.
Private property, only for guests of Necker Island.
Clean sandy beach, good launch spot.
Very small beach with sand and grass. Not much space.
